greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Roman numerals with 1 letter, in numerical order; then those with 2 letters, etc.
comment: The sequence is finite because 3999 is the largest number that can be written using the symbols I,V,X,L,C,D,M. -  _J. Lowell_, Nov 17 2020

The Romans had symbols for 5000, 10000, 50000, and 100000, but they have no simple equivalents in our current alphabet. See The Book of Numbers, p. 19. The symbol for 100000 is sometimes represented by (((|))). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 28 2020
reference: J. H. Conway and R. K. Guy, The Book of Numbers, Copernicus Press, NY, 1996, p. 19.
example: Written in Roman numerals, the sequence reads: I, V, X, L, C, D, M, II, IV, VI, IX, XI, XV, XX, XL, LI, LV, LX, XC, CI, CV, CX, CL, CC, CD, DI, DV, DX, DL, DC, CM, MI, MV, MX, MV, MC, MD, MM, III, VII, XII, ... - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 12 2015
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, _J. H. Conway_ and John Jackson (ab158(AT)freenet.uchsc.edu)
ext: More terms from _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 12 2015
